The Chancellor is being urged to make good on the Vote Leave’s campaign promise to protect £653m of EU funding for the region in his first Autumn Statement this week. 
Sedgefield MP Phil Wilson has said the Government must use the Autumn Statement on Wednesday to guarantee the millions of pounds of EU funding that has been promised to the North East. 
Mr Wilson is campaigning on behalf of Open Britain, a group which aims to keep the UK close to Europe and in the single market after Brexit . 
According to campaigners’ research, money from the European Regional Development Fund, European Social Fund, European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and European Maritime and Fisheries Fund totalling £653m is due to be given to the North East over the 2017-2020 period. 
During the referendum campaign, Vote Leave said that all EU funding programmes promised until 2020 would be guaranteed by the UK government. 
However, the Chancellor has so far only pledged to match funding for projects that “meet UK priorities and value for money criteria” – leaving the possibility that the North East could lose out on huge amounts of funding. 
Mr Wilson said: “EU funding is so important for the North East, supporting our businesses and public services. Now it’s time for the Government to keep its promise and guarantee that this money will be matched until 2020. 
“At the Autumn Statement on Wednesday, I am calling on the Chancellor to stand up for the North East and protect jobs and services in our communities. 
“There is a mandate for Brexit, but not a Brexit that would leave our communities worse off.” Read More North East business group says Chancellor must replace EU funding for the region 
Pressure is building on Tory MP Phillip Hammond ahead of his first Autumn Statement. 
The Chancellor is believed to have been told by Whitehall to deliver a Budget that boosts people who are “just about managing”. 
In his conference speech given last month Mr Hammond offered some certainty to British businesses and organisations bidding for EU funding. 
He said: “I’ve already guaranteed the funding for projects signed prior to this year’s Autumn Statement. Today, I can go further. The Treasury will offer a guarantee to bidders whose projects meet UK priorities and value for money criteria that if they secure multi-year EU funding before we exit we will guarantee those payments after Britain has left the EU.” Like us on Facebook
